column2: (reading the comics) Eh..., I don\xc2\x92t, I don\xc2\x92t know.'
What?'
Well, as old as he is in dog years, do you think Snoopy should still\nbe allowed to fly this thing?'
Rachel?'
Yeah.'
Do you remember when you first came here, how you spent two weeks\ngetting trained by another waitress?'
Oh, sure! Do you need me to train somebody new?'
(laughs) Good one. Actually, ah, Terry wants you to take the training\nagain, whenever.'
(to Chandler) Eh, do you believe that?'
(thinks about it) Yeah?'

So that\xc2\x92s two boxes of the Holiday Macaroons. On behalf of the Brown
Birds of America, I salute you. (Does the Brown Bird salute, she blows on a bird call,
then holds her hand, palm facing out, next to her face, and then waves it like a bird
flapping it\xc2\x92s wings.)'
Just admit it Chandler, you have no backhand.'
Excuse me little one, I have a very solid backhand.'
Shielding your face and shrieking like a girl... is not a backhand.'
I was shrieking... like a Marine.'

All right here. Watch me execute the three \xc2\x91P\xc2\x92s of championship
play. Power. (swings the racquet) Precision. (swings the racquet.) and penache. (does a
backswing and hits Sarah who\xc2\x92s started up the stairs, knocking her down, they both
watch in horror.)'
You broke a little girl\xc2\x92s leg?!!'
I know. I feel horrible. Okay.'
(reading the paper) Says here that a muppet got whacked on Seasame\nStreet last night. (to Ross) Where exactly were around ten-ish?'
Well, I\xc2\x92m gonna go see her. I want to bring her something, what do\nyou think she\xc2\x92ll like?'
Maybe a Hello Kitty doll, the ability to walk...'
I\xc2\x92m gonna get back to retraining. (gets up)'
All right, see you guys. (starts to leave)'
Look out kids, he\xc2\x92s coming! (Ross continues to leave with his\nhead down in shame.)'
And I gotta go sell some Christmas trees.'
Have fun. Oh wait, no, don\xc2\x92t! I forgot I am totally against that\nnow.'
What? Me having a job?'
No, no, I am against innocent trees being cut down in their prime, and\ntheir, their corpses grotesquely dressed in like tinsel and twinkly lights. (to Joey) Hey,\nhow do you sleep at night?'

Well, I\xc2\x92m pretty tired from lugging the trees around all day. Hey,\nPhoebe listen, you got this all wrong. Those trees were born to be Christmas trees, their\nfulfilling their life purpose, by, by making people happy.'
Really?'
Yes. Yes, and ah, ah, the trees are happy too, because for most of\nthem, it\xc2\x92s the only chance to see New York.'
...and after you\xc2\x92ve delivered the drinks, you take the empty\ntray....'
Gunther, Gunther, please, I\xc2\x92ve worked here for two and a half\nyears, I know the empty trays go over there. (points to the counter.)'
What if you put them here. (sets the empty tray on another stack of\nempty trays on the back counter.)'
Huh. Well, y'know that\xc2\x92s actually a really good idea, because that\nway they\xc2\x92ll be closer to the mugs. Y'know what, you should have the other waitresses\ndo that too."
They already do. That\xc2\x92s why they call it the \xc2\x91tray\nspot.\xc2\x92'
Gee, I always heard them talk about that, I just always thought that it\nwas a club they went to. Oh God, I\xc2\x92m, I\xc2\x92m sorry. (walks away)'
It\xc2\x92s all right. Sweetheart.'
So, this must be kinda neat for ya, huh? I mean, your Dad tells me that\nyou get a couple of days off school, and you, you ah, don\xc2\x92t have to sell those\ncookies anymore. '
Well, I kinda wanted to sell the cookies. The girl who sells the most\nwins a trip to Spacecamp, and gets to sit in a real space shuttle.'
Wow, you ah, you really like all this space stuff, huh?'
Yeah. My Dad says if I spend as much time helping him clean apartments,\nas I do daydreaming about outer space, he\xc2\x92d be able to afford a trip to the Taj\nMahal.'
I think you would have to clean a whole lot of apartments to go all the\nway to India.'
No. The one in Atlantic City, Dad loves the slots. He says he\xc2\x92s\ngonna double the college money my Grandma left me.'
Huh. Well, good luck to Dad. Say, how many more boxes would you have to\nsell in order to win?'
The girl who won last year sold four hundred and seventy-five.'
Yeah.'
So far, I\xc2\x92ve sold seventy-five.'
Four hundred, huh? Well, that sounds do-able. (starts to get out his\nwallet) How much are the boxes?'
Five dollars a box.'
(puts away his wallet) And what is second prize?'
A ten speed bike. But, I\xc2\x92d rather have something my Dad\ncouldn\xc2\x92t sell.'
Well, that makes sense.'
Could you do me one favor, if it\xc2\x92s not too much trouble?'
Yeah, Sarah, anything.'

Could you pull open the curtains for me? The astronauts from the space\nshuttle are gonna be on the news, and since we don\xc2\x92t have a TV, the lady across the\nalley said she\xc2\x92d push hers up to a window, so I could watch it.'
(looking through her peephole, we see Ross standing in the hallway.)\nYesss?'
Hi, I\xc2\x92m selling Brown Bird cookies.'
You\xc2\x92re no Brown Bird, I can see you through my peephole.'
No, hi, I\xc2\x92m, I\xc2\x92m an honorary Brown Bird (does the Brown Bird\nsalute.)'
What does that mean?'
Ah, well, it means that I can sell cookies, but I\xc2\x92m not invited to\nsleep-overs.'
I can dial 9-1-1 at the touch of a button, y'know. Now, go away!"
No, please, please, um, it\xc2\x92s for a poor little girl who wants to go\nto Spacecamp more than anything in the world.'
I\xc2\x92m pressing, a policeman is on his way.'
Okay, okay! I\xc2\x92m going. I\xc2\x92m going. (goes across the hall to knock\non another door.)'
I can still see you!'
All right!!'
(walking up to Joey) Hey.'
Hey. What, what are you doing here?'
Well, I-I thought a lot about what you said, and um, I realilized duh,\nall right maybe I was a little judgmental. Yeah, (looks at the tree) oh, but oh...'
Look now, Phoebe remember, hey, their just fulfilling their Christmas....'
Destiny.'
Sure.'
Yes.'
All right.'
Okay. (One of Joey\xc2\x92s co-workers, walks by with a dead tree.) Yikes!\nThat one doesn\xc2\x92t look very fulfilled.'
Oh, that\xc2\x92s, that\xc2\x92s ah, one of the old ones, he\xc2\x92s just\ntaking it to the back.'
You keep the old ones in the back, that is so ageist.'
Well we have to make room for the fresh ones.'
So, what happens to the old guys?'
Well, they go into the chipper.'

Why, do I have a feeling that\xc2\x92s not as happy as it sounds? (Joey
points out one going into the chipper to her, as this haunty, demonic music starts to play
in the background) No! Nooooo!!! (she winces in horror and hides her face against
Joey\xc2\x92s shoulder, as she sees the tree spit out from the chipper.)'
(to the guy operating the chipper) Hey! Hey!! (makes the \xc2\x91cut\nit\xc2\x92 motion with his hands)'
...and these come in the shapes of your favourite Christmas characters,\nSanta, Rudolph, and Baby Jesus.'
All right, I\xc2\x92ll take a box of the cream filled Jesus\xc2\x92s.'
Wait a minute, one box! Come on, I\xc2\x92m trying to send a little girl to\nSpacecamp, I\xc2\x92m putting you down for five boxes. Chandler, what about you?'
Ahh, do you have any coconut flavoured deities?'
No, but ah, there\xc2\x92s coconut in the Hanukkah Menoreoes. I tell you\nwhat, I\xc2\x92ll put you down for eight boxes, one for each night.'
Mon?'

All right, I\xc2\x92ll take one box of the mint treasures, just one, and\nthat\xc2\x92s it. I-I started gaining weight after I joined the Brown Birds. (to Ross)\nRemember, how Dad bought all my boxes and I ate them all?'

Ah, no Mon, Dad had to buy everyone of your boxes because
you ate them all. But ah, y'know I\xc2\x92m sure that\xc2\x92s not gonna happen this time, why
don\xc2\x92t I put you down for three of the mint treasures and just a couple of the
Rudolph\xc2\x92s."
No.'
Oh, come on, now you know you want \xc2\x91em.'
Don\xc2\x92t, don\xc2\x92t, don\xc2\x92t, don\xc2\x92t, don\xc2\x92t do this.'
I\xc2\x92ll tell you what Mon, I\xc2\x92ll give you the first box for free.'
(she reaches out for it and stops) Oh God! I gotta go! (runs out)'
Come on! All the cool kids are eating \xc2\x91em! (chases after her.)'
And when you have a second later, I wanna show you why we don\xc2\x92t\njust trap spiders under coffee mugs and leave them there.'
(sitting down next to Chandler) I\xc2\x92m training to be better at a job\nthat I hate, my life officially sucks.'
Look Rach, wasn\xc2\x92t this supposed to a temporary thing? I thought you\nwanted to do fashion stuff?'
Well, yeah! I\xc2\x92m still pursuing that.'
How... exactly are you pursuing that? Y'know other than sending out\nresumes like what, two years ago?"
Well, I\xc2\x92m also sending out.... good thoughts.'
If you ask me, as long as you got this job, you\xc2\x92ve got nothing\npushing you to get another one. You need the fear.'
The fear?'
He\xc2\x92s right, if you quit this job, you then have motivation to go\nafter a job you really want.'
Well then how come you\xc2\x92re still at a job that you hate, I mean why\ndon\xc2\x92t you quit and get \xc2\x91the fear\xc2\x92?'
Because, I\xc2\x92m too afraid.'
I don\xc2\x92t know, I mean I would give anything to work for a designer,\ny'know, or a buyer.... Oh, I just don\xc2\x92t want to be 30 and still work here."
Yeah, that\xc2\x92d be much worse than being 28, and still\nworking here.'
Rachel?'
Yeah.'
Remind me to review with you which pot is decaf and which is regular.'
Can\xc2\x92t I just look at the handles on them?'
You would think.'

Okay, fine. Gunther, y'know what, I am a terrible waitress, do you know
why I\xc2\x92m a terrible waitress? Because, I don\xc2\x92t care. I don\xc2\x92t care. I
don\xc2\x92t care which pot is regular and which pot is decaf, I don\xc2\x92t care where the
tray spot is, I just don\xc2\x92t care, this is not what I want to do. So I don\xc2\x92t think
I should do it anymore. I\xc2\x92m gonna give you my weeks notice."
What?!'
Gunther, I quit.'
(to Joey) Does this mean we\xc2\x92re gonna have to start paying for\ncoffee? (Joey shrugs his shoulders.)'
....and 12, 22, 18, four... (Chandler starts laughing) What?'
I spelled out boobies.'
(comes up and starts looking through Ross\xc2\x92s cookie supply) Ross,\nbut me down for another box of the mint treasures, okay. Where, where are the mint\ntreasures?'
Ah, we\xc2\x92re out. I sold them all.'
What?'
Monica, I\xc2\x92m cutting you off.'
No. No, just, just, just a couple more boxes. It-it-it\xc2\x92s no big\ndeal, all right, I\xc2\x92m-I\xc2\x92m cool. You gotta help me out with a couple more boxes!'
Mon, look at yourself. You have cookie on your neck.'
(covers her neck) Oh God! (runs to the bathroom)'
So, how many have you sold so far?'
Check this out. Five hundred and seventeen boxes!'
Oh my God, how did you do that?'

Okay, the other night I was leaving the museum just as \xc2\x91Laser
Floyd\xc2\x92 was letting out of the planetarium, without even trying I sold 50 boxes!
That\xc2\x92s when it occurred to me, the key to my success, \xc2\x91the munchies.\xc2\x92 So I
ah, started hitting the NYU dorms around midnight. I am selling cookies by the case. They
call me
(entering) Okay, stop what you\xc2\x92re doing, I need envelope stuffers,\nI need stamp lickers.....'
Well hey, who did these resumes for ya?'
Me! On my computer.'
Well you sure used a large font.'
Eh, yeah, well ah, waitress at a coffee shop and cheer squad\nco-captain only took up so much room.'
Hey-hey-hey that\xc2\x92s funny! Your funny Chandler! Your a funny guy!\nYou wanna know what else is really funny?!'
Something else I might have said?'
I don\xc2\x92t know, I don\xc2\x92t know, weren\xc2\x92t you the guy that told\nme to quit my job when I had absolutely nothing else to do. Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha!!'
Sweetie, calm down, it\xc2\x92s gonna be okay.'

No, it\xc2\x92s not gonna be okay Ross, tomorrow is my last day, and I\ndon\xc2\x92t have a lead. Okay, y'know what, I\xc2\x92m just gonna, I\xc2\x92m just gonna call\nGunther and I\xc2\x92m gonna tell him, I\xc2\x92m not quitting."
You-you-you don\xc2\x92t wanna give into the fear.'
You and your stupid fear. I hate your fear. I would like to take you and\nyour fear.... '
(entering, interrupting Rachel) Hey! I got great news!'
Run, Joey! Run for your life! (runs out)'
What? Rachel, listen, have you ever heard of Fortunata Fashions?'
No.'
Well my old man is doing a plumbing job down there and he heard they have\nan opening. So, you want me to see if I can get you an interview?'
Oh my God! Yes, I would love that, oh, that is soo sweet, Joey.'
Not a problem.'
Thanks.'
And now for the great news.'
What, that wasn\xc2\x92t the great news?'
Only if you think it\xc2\x92s better than this... (holds up an aerosol can)\nsnow-in-a-can!! I got it at work. Mon, you want me to decorate the window, give it a kind\nof Christmas lookie.'
Christmas cookie?'
Okay, and ah, this one here is a Douglas Fir, now it\xc2\x92s a little more\nmoney, but you get a nicer smell.'
Looks good. I\xc2\x92ll take it.'
(running up carrying a tree) Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait! No, no, you\ndon\xc2\x92t want that one. No, you can have this cool brown one. (points to the almost dead\ntree she has)'
It\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s almost dead!'
Okay but that\xc2\x92s why you have to buy it, so it can fulfil it\xc2\x92s\nChristmas destiny, otherwise there gonna throw it into the chipper. Tell him, Joey'
Yeah, the ah, trees that don\xc2\x92t fulfil their Christmas destiny are\nthrown in the chipper.'
I-I think I\xc2\x92m gonna look around a little bit more.'
Pheebs, you gotta stop this, I working on commission here.'
(entering) Hey, guys. I\xc2\x92m here to pick out my Christmas tree.'
Well look no further, (shows her the dead one) this one\xc2\x92s yours!\nAhhh.'
Is this the one that I threw out last year?'

All right y'know what, nevermind! Everyone wants to have a green one!\nI\xc2\x92m sorry, I\xc2\x92m sorry, I didn\xc2\x92t mean to get so emotional, I guess it\xc2\x92s\njust the holidays, it\xc2\x92s hard."
Oh honey, is that \xc2\x91cause your Mom died around Christmas?'
Oh, I wasn\xc2\x92t even thinking about that.'
Oh. (turns and looks at Joey, who gives a \xc2\x91way-to-go\xc2\x92 thumbs\nup and smile.)'
(to the girl sitting next to him) Hi there. How many, how many ah, did you\nsell?'
I\xc2\x92m not gonna tell you! You\xc2\x92re the bad man who broke\nSarah\xc2\x92s leg.'
Hey now! That was an accident, okay.'
You\xc2\x92re a big scrud.'
What\xc2\x92s a scrud?'
Why don\xc2\x92t you look in the mirror, scrud.'
I don\xc2\x92t have too. I can just look at you.'
All right girls, and man. Let\xc2\x92s see your final tallies. (all the\ngirls raise their hands) Ohhhh, Debbie, (looks at her form) 321 boxes of cookies, (to\nDebbie) Very nice.'
(to himself) Not nice enough.'
Charla, 278. Sorry, dear, but still good.'
(to himself) Good for a scrud.'
Oh, yes Elizabeth. Ah, 871.'
That\xc2\x92s crap!! Sister Brown Bird. (to Elizabeth) Good going. (does the\nsalute)'
Who\xc2\x92s next? (goes over and stands behind Ross, who\xc2\x92s\nfeverishly writing on his form, and clears her throat to get his attention.)'
Hi there!'
Hi. And batting for Sarah, Ross Geller, 872. Although, it looks like you\nbought an awful lot of cookies yourself.'
Um, that is because my doctor says that I have a very serious....\nnuget.... diffency.'
Tell us what happened, Brown Bird Ross.'
Well, I lost. Some little girl loaned her uniform to her nineteen year old\nsister, who went down to the U.S.S. Nimitz, and sold over 2,000 boxes.'
(to Rachel, who\xc2\x92s entering) Hey! How\xc2\x92d the interview go?'
Oh, I blew it. I wouldn\xc2\x92t of even hired me.'
Oh, come here sweetie, listen, you\xc2\x92re gonna go on like a thousand\ninterviews before you get a job. (she glares at him) That\xc2\x92s not how that was supposed\nto come out.'
This is the worst Christmas ever.'
Y'know what Rach, maybe you should just, y'know stay here at the\ncoffee house."

I can\xc2\x92t! It\xc2\x92s too late! Terry already hired that girl over\nthere. (points to her) Look at her, she\xc2\x92s even got waitress experience. Last night\nshe was teaching everybody how to make napkin.... (starts to cry) swans.'
That word was swans.'
Well seeing that drunk Santa wet himself, really perked up my\nChristmas.'
Oh! Oh my God!'
(jumping up from behind the couch) Merry Christmas!!'
You saved them! You guys! Oh God, you\xc2\x92re the best!'
It\xc2\x92s like \xc2\x91Night of the Living Dead Christmas Trees.\xc2\x92'
(answering the phone) Hello? (listens) Yeah, this is she. (listens) Oh!\nYou\xc2\x92re kidding! You\xc2\x92re kidding! (listens) Oh thank you! I love you!'
Sure, everybody loves a kidder.'
(hanging up the phone) I got the job!'
That\xc2\x92s great! Hey! Excellent!'
Oh, God bless us, everyone.'
Here we go. I\xc2\x92m serving my last cup of coffee. (the gang starts\nhumming the graduation theme) There you go. (hands it to Chandler) Enjoy. (they all cheer)'
(to Ross) Should I tell her I ordered tea?'
No. '

Um, excuse me, everyone. Ah, this is my last night working here, and I
ah, just wanted say that I made some really good friends working here, and ah, it\xc2\x92s
just time to move on. (at the counter Gunther starts to cry and runs into the back room)
Ah, and no offence to everybody who ah, still works here, you have no idea how good it
feels to say that as of this moment I will never have to make coffee again.'
Now Mr. Kaplan Sr. likes his coffee strong, so your gonna\nuse two bags instead of one, see. Now pay attention, \xc2\x91cause this part\xc2\x92s tricky,\nsee some people use filters just once.'

I\xc2\x92m, I\xc2\x92m sorry you didn\xc2\x92t get to go to Spacecamp, and
I\xc2\x92m hoping that maybe somehow, this may make up for it. Presenting Sarah
Tuttle\xc2\x92s Private Very Special Spacecamp!! (opens the door and Chandler and Joey jump
up, their apartment is decorated like outer space, one of the leather chairs is covered in
tinfoil.)'
Really Mr. Geller, you don\xc2\x92t have to do this.'
Oh come on! Here we go! (picks her up and puts her in the chair) Stand by\nfor mission countdown!'
(simulating an echo) Ten, ten.., nine, nine, nine....,\neight, eight, eight... (Chandler hits him in the back of the head) Okay, Blast off!'
I\xc2\x92m an alien. I\xc2\x92m an alien.'
Oh no! An asteroid! (throws the soccer ball off the back of Joey\xc2\x92s\nhead.)'
